document.docAuthor: Delgado, Juan A. & Palma, Ricardo L.
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the genus Podaena Ordish (Insecta: Coleoptera: Hydraenidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the genus Podaena Ordish (Insecta: Coleoptera: Hydraenidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Departamento de Zoología y Antropología Física, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de Murcia, 30100, Murcia, Spain.
Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Wellington, New Zealand. E-mail: ricardop @ tepapa. govt. nz

bibRefCitation.author: Ordish, R. G.
bibRefCitation.refString: Ordish, R. G. (1984) Hydraenidae (Insecta: Coleoptera). Fauna of New Zealand, 6, 1 - 56.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis. Male ( Fig. 101 ) body length (taken from anterior margin of labrum to elytral apex) 1.90 mm; female body length 1.98 mm. Externally similar to
P. dentipalpis
,
P. obscura
,
P. trochanteralis
,
P. latipalpis
,
P. hauturu
and
P. moanaiti
, but distinguished from all these species by its less modified male palps with a much reduced chaetotaxy, and the last two distal palpomeres without ventral grooves ( Figs 21–22 ). Among the species with less or not modified male palps,
P. kuscheli
can be clearly separated from
P. maclellani
,
P. mariae
and
P. glabriventris
by the male foretibiae (compare Figs 31, 35 with Figs 25–30 ), and from
P. aotea
by the chaetotaxy and length of the male palps, and by the male foretibiae, especially by the position of tibial spines 1 and 2 (compare Figs 31, 35 with Figs 39, 43 respectively).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 100. Habitus of
P. glabriventris
(Flora Hut). Scale = 0.5 mm.

FIGURE 101. Habitus of
P. kuscheli (Lake Paringa)
. Scale = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The male foretibiae of
P. kuscheli
have a conspicuous tibial spine 2, placed in the most distal position among all species, hence it is widely separated from tibial spine 1 ( Figs 31, 35 ). Metaventrite with a glabrous central area as in Fig. 47 , and terminalia similar to those of close species ( Figs 54 , 65, 68 ). Male genitalia ( Figs 81−82 ) with the proximal half of the main piece cylindrical, and a distal half progressively flattened, foliaceous, and very unsclerotized, almost colourless. Distal lobe equally colourless and hardly distinguishable from the main piece, with an evertable flagellum, but variable morphology, not useful for species identification. Spermatheca ( Fig. 87 ) with a sinuous tapering central piece, ending in a long thin distal duct.

Note.
Since
P. kuscheli
is not known from the Nelson area ( NN ), the male genitalia figured by Ordish (1984: 49 , fig. 82) is incorrectly labelled as from “ Flora Creek ”, a locality situated in the Nelson area
.
Distribution. As in Fig. 98 . Restricted to the west coast of the South Island.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype : South Island : Westland ( WD ):
Male – “Hercules Ck., Mt. / Hercules WD / 30 Mar. 73 / G. Kuschel ”.

subSubSection.paragraph:

:

29 Mar 1973
/ G.K. + J.McB.”
